docs.lead_paragraph: THE Hebron Lions Club has been on the giving end for several decades. They have mastered both the large gesture, like donating thousands of dollars to the Fidelco Guide Dog Foundation, and the small, building a safety fence for a single mother with an autistic child. They are, like many charitable organizations, a measure of how a small group in a small town can make a difference. But this month, the Lions Club have been on the receiving end, after vandals destroyed buildings on Jan. 5 at the club's fairgrounds, the site of the Hebron Harvest Fair, the Lions' largest moneymaking event, and burned down the fair's largest building. The club estimated the damage at more than $1 million.

headline.main: Lions Find Charity Is Two-Way Street

docs.abstract: Hebron Lions Club in Connecticut reportedly receives large outpouring of good will and donated items and services from dozens of charitable groups and local businesses to help repair buildings at club's fairgrounds destroyed and burned by vandals; fairgrounds is site of annual Hebron Harvest Fair, club's largest moneymaking event; club estimates damage at more than $1 million; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THE Hebron Lions Club has been on the giving end for several decades. They have mastered both the large gesture, like donating thousands of dollars to the Fidelco Guide Dog Foundation, and the small, building a safety fence for a single mother with...

docs.lead_paragraph: The unifying theme on domestic policy in President Bush's Inaugural Address on Thursday will be the president's vision of an ''ownership society'' as he tries to galvanize support for fundamental changes he wants in Social Security, tax policy and other areas, administration officials say. ''When people have a stake in something,'' Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said in an interview on Friday, explaining the president's rationale, ''it makes the whole social system work better.''

headline.main: Bush to Return to 'Ownership Society' Theme in Push for Social Security Changes

docs.abstract: Unifying theme of Pres Bush's Inaugural Address will be vision of 'ownership society'; boldest example of Bush's policy is intensifying campaign to radically alter Social Security; Republicans mostly believe role of government is to foster greater individual economic achievement, even if it leads to more economic inequality; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The president's vision of an "ownership society" will be the unifying theme as he tries to galvanize support for fundamental changes in Social Security, tax policy and other areas.

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN in electoral exile, Newt Gingrich has the political power to stir things up with a single provocative remark. Last week, when asked on ''Fox News Sunday'' if he might consider a bid for the White House in 2008, Mr. Gingrich, the former House speaker, replied, ''I'm not ruling that out.'' That set conservative commentators and Web sites buzzing. They noted that his answer came a day before the publication of his new book, ''Winning the Future,'' which offers a presidential-like agenda for big issues like national security and health care. His book tour, they added, will take him through early primary states. ''We'll see if he's running for president,'' said Jeffrey A. Eisenach, a Gingrich protégé and a co-founder of the conservative Progress and Freedom Foundation, in an interview. ''It would be exciting.''
docs.abstract: New Gingrich, former House speaker, has become broker of ideas and influence in field of health care policy, particularly conservative notion of applying principles of 'ownership society' to medicine through health savings accounts and consumer-directed health care; idea is to give individuals tax breaks to assume responsibility for paying more of their own medical costs and to rely less on government and insurers; believes market forces will bring more options, lower prices and higher quality to health care; another focus of his, one on which he often works with liberals, is to increase investment in health information technology in order to reduce medical errors and improve efficiency; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich is probably the most visible spokesman for a set of ideas about health care that is gaining support in the Bush administration and in business.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The myth about malpractice litigation is that minimizing medical errors and correcting insurance company abuses might make changing medical liability laws unnecessary.
docs.abstract: Dr Jeffrey Frankel letter holds that as long as good doctors practicing good medicine are vulnerable to unwarranted malpractice lawsuits, they will see patients as potential adversaries, practice defensively and add billions of dollars to health care costs each year
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The myth about malpractice litigation is that minimizing medical errors and correcting insurance company abuses might make changing medical liability laws unnecessary.

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE thousands of other Americans without comprehensive health insurance, Rosa Metz has faced difficult decisions at her local pharmacy. She recently had the flu and knew that she could not afford both the antibiotics her doctor prescribed and the $75 worth of medication she needed to treat her high blood pressure. After much hesitation, Ms. Metz, a 44-year-old resident of Mount Vernon, opted to put off buying her heart medication until her next paycheck, two weeks later. ''It was a terrible decision to have to make,'' she said. ''I was really scared, but I just didn't have the money to do anything else.''
docs.abstract: Discount drug program in Westchester County, NY, which offers savings on medications imported from Canada, is revamped to eliminate enrollment fees and add chain drugstores to list of participating pharmacies (M)
docs.snippet: LIKE thousands of other Americans without comprehensive health insurance, Rosa Metz has faced difficult decisions at her local pharmacy. She recently had the flu and knew that she could not afford both the antibiotics her doctor prescribed and the...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN David Dorfman first drove up Interstate 95 to this historic whaling port 25 years ago, he was an ebullient 24-year-old graduate student working toward a dance degree from Connecticut College and a career as a choreographer in New York. ''My goal was to make it as a freelance artist, with enough money to afford a good apartment, health care, the works,'' he said.

headline.main: Now Performing on Campus: The Dancing Professors

docs.abstract: Choreographer David Dorfman has found satisfaction in transition from role as head of dance company to professor of dance at alma mater Connecticut College; he and other choreographers are finding new measures of success and financial security in lives in academia; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With resources diminishing and costs rising, struggling choreographers are finding a refuge in academia.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In 2002, the Harvard School of Public Health and the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation conducted a study that found that more than 35 percent of the 831 American physicians they surveyed said that either they or members of their families had experienced medical errors in the course of being treated; many said that the errors had ''serious health consequences,'' like death, long-term disability or severe pain.
docs.abstract: Letter by lawyer Robert B Linder responds to Jan 9 editorial; holds that we need meaningful reform within health care industry to prevent medical errors; says Bush administration's policy is based on enhancement of insurance companies' profits at expense of general public; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Another example of malpractice mythology is the common misconception that a malpractice lawsuit resulting in payment to a plaintiff represents ''bad medicine.''
docs.abstract: Dr Suzanne Frye letter responds to Jan 9 editorial; holds that while imposing caps on awards is no real answer, editorial's suggestion that malpractice problem could be solved by cutting down on malpractice is simplistic and off target
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Another example of malpractice mythology is the common misconception that a malpractice lawsuit resulting in payment to a plaintiff represents ''bad medicine.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Jayson Williams has left the New Jersey estate he called ''Who Knew?'' -- where the wealth and excess of his gregarious playing days led to tragedy -- and has landed in the Idaho outpost of Nampa, about 20 miles west of Boise. Williams is trying to rehabilitate his pro basketball career while waiting for his retrial on a charge of reckless manslaughter in the death in February 2002 of a chauffeur, Costas Christofi. He is also awaiting sentencing for his attempt to cover up his involvement in the shooting at his estate.

headline.main: Williams's Attempt at a Comeback Begins in Idaho

docs.abstract: Former New Jersey Nets player Jayson Williams starts his professional comeback with Idaho Stampede of Continental Basketball Association while waiting to be sentenced for role in shooting death of his chauffeur Costas Christofi; hopes to return to NBA after six-year hiatus that started when Williams broke his leg in 1999; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Jayson Williams, 36, is trying to rehabilitate his pro basketball career in the C.B.A. while waiting for his retrial on a charge of reckless manslaughter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pressed by rising costs, the states are scrambling for ways to keep millions of people who are released from jails and prisons each year from coming back. An obvious first step would be to abolish senselessly punitive laws that make it difficult for felons to reconstruct their lives, like those in all 50 states that bar ex-convicts from occupations that have nothing at all to do with their crimes. Another prudent step would be to create high-quality programs that provide newly released people with counseling and job placement. Perhaps most crucially, those who qualify need assistance in getting back their federal disability and Medicaid benefits; inmates typically lose such benefits when they find themselves locked up for 30 days or more. The loss of benefits is especially devastating for the mentally ill, who make up one-sixth of the prison population and who are particularly susceptible to recidivism. Most of them get psychiatric drugs and treatment for the first time in jail. They often improve quickly, but deteriorate just as fast when they are released without being re-enrolled in federal disability programs or Medicaid, which would give them access to medication and psychiatric care. Homeless, delusional and out of control, they are inevitably rearrested for behaviors related to their illnesses. Many of them come back to jail so regularly that corrections workers call them ''frequent fliers.''
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that mentally ill inmates who are released from prison without access to care drive up incarceration costs by going back again and again; maintains that eligible inmates should have their disability and Medicaid benefits in hand before they leave prison; holds that setting up new administrative process might not be easy, but it would more than pay for itself down line
docs.snippet: We need a system to ensure that prisoners, especially those that are mentally ill, receive the Medicaid and disability benefits they need once they rejoin society.
